image.altText: Firefighters in Tara rushing to help extinguish a blaze.

items.synopsis: Firefighters were kept busy overnight with dozens ofÂ bushfire warnings across southern Queensland and northern New South Wales with more property losses confirmed. Follow live

title.children: Number of homes lost in Queensland surpasses 2019 Black Summer bushfire season with more property losses confirmed

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Southern Downs Mayor Vic Pennisi has just spoken to News Breakfast: "I can confirm that there's been four homes lost in Wallangarra. However, the danger at this point in time has passed. People are beginning to move back into their homes which is great. "The fires when through very, very quickly from when the evacuation was called to when the fire got there. In the hills, they just move at a great pace of knots, especially when they're fanned with the wind. "Of course, the loss of any property would be devastating for those residents who have been affected. "And you know, my heart goes out to those people who have lost their properties. You know that your home is your castle. You've got so many family memories in there. You know, kids and photos and all those sorts of things. So I can't begin to imagine what those people who have lost their homes are going through at the moment. "But, you know, we didn't lose any people and you know, that's our primary concern is to make sure that our people are as safe as possible. And our Fire and Emergency Services have done a wonderful job."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Four more houses confirmed lost in Wallangarra overnight

children.content: (ABC News)
Southern Downs Mayor Vic Pennisi has just spoken to News Breakfast:
"I can confirm that
there's been four homes lost in Wallangarra
. However, the danger at this point in time has passed. People are beginning to move back into their homes which is great.

"The fires when through very, very quickly from when the evacuation was called to when the fire got there. In the hills, they just move at a great pace of knots, especially when they're fanned with the wind.
"Of course, the loss of any property would be devastating for those residents who have been affected.

"And you know, my heart goes out to those people who have lost their properties. You know that your home is your castle. You've got so many family memories in there. You know, kids and photos and all those sorts of things. So I can't begin to imagine what those people who have lost their homes are going through at the moment.
"But, you know,
we didn't lose any people
and you know, that's our primary concern is to make sure that our people are as safe as possible. And our Fire and Emergency Services have done a wonderful job."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Kirsten Webster and Danielle Mahe The Rural Fire Service believes an arsonist is active on the Gold Coast hinterland. Crews were called back to the Bonogin Valley at 6:40am on Wednesday, following reports a fire they believe was deliberately lit yesterday reignited. Six fires were lit along a road on Tuesday, prompting crews to respond rapidly to stop them spreading in the dry, hot conditions. Chief Superintendent Alan Gillespie said crews managed to get to the fires quickly. "We were able to scramble resources fairly quickly and they are all out but we will be quite vigilant" Mr Gillespie said. "It is just incredible that people are doing stupid things like that," he said A Queensland Fire and Emergency Services (QFES) spokesman said the reignited fire had been extinguished. Mr Gillespie says they have a number of leads, and that police are investigating. "I just can't understand the mentality of people who go out and put the community and our firefighters on the line and under risk just for some perverse thrill of seeing vehicles responding to fires." Queensland Police have been contacted for comment.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Authorities believe arsonist is active in Gold Coast hinterland

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The loss of homes around Tara, on Queensland's Western Downs, has now surpassed the total number of homes lost in Queensland during the 2019 Black Summer fire season. As firefighters have battled blazes in that region for nearly two weeks, with four houses confirmed destroyed in Wallangarra overnight, and 53 destroyed around Tara, for a total of 57, compared to 49 across the state in 2019. Paul McVeigh, mayor of Western Downs Regional Council, said the loss had had a huge impact on the community. "The resilience of our community is very strong â¦ but to be hit with so much devastation is a real challenge," he said. "Obviously housing will be our greatest need."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: More homes lost in Qld than in 2019 Black Summer

children.content: The loss of homes has had a huge impact on Tara.
(ABC News: Chris Gillette)
The loss of homes around Tara, on Queensland's Western Downs, has now surpassed the total number of homes lost in Queensland during the 2019 Black Summer fire season.

As firefighters have battled blazes in that region for nearly two weeks, with four houses confirmed destroyed in Wallangarra overnight, and 53 destroyed around Tara, for a total of 57, compared to 49 across the state in 2019.
Paul McVeigh, mayor of Western Downs Regional Council,
said the loss had had a huge impact on the community.
"The resilience of our community is very strong â¦ but to be hit with so much devastation is a real challenge," he said.
"Obviously housing will be our greatest need."

image.altText: Israeli forces' flares light up the night sky in northern Gaza Strip

items.synopsis: Hamas's tunnels under Gaza are a prime target for Israel as it expands its ground offensive inÂ the north of the enclave after three weeks of aerial bombardment.

title.children: Ground-level clashes intensify as Israeli military confirms deadly strikes on Gaza refugee camp

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here in Jerusalem, you see Israeli Defense Force (IDF) soldiers everywhere. Israelis serve in the military once they turn 18, with men serving 32 months and women doing 24 months. After that, almost everyone remains in the reserves until they turn 40. Israel summoned roughly 360,000 reservists to join the fight against Hamas after the attack on October 7. Many of them were living overseas and they dropped everything to return home. The ABC met up with Australian-Israeli Yaacov Travitz in Jerusalem. He was in Australia when the attack happened, and immediately hopped on a plane. "I was not expecting to come back to fight. I hate fighting. I'm over it. I spent a lot of my life fighting, both in service as well as afterwards in private security. I thought I was done with it but I felt like I was needed and my talents could be put to good use to protect people. " Yaacov's daughter lives in Jerusalem with his ex-partner, and being here for her was also a big reason for him to come back. "My hope is that I can keep her safe for long enough until this is over. And then everything goes back to normal, she goes to school, her mum goes to work. And everything just goes back to normal, with people just trying to live without the hate, without the violence."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian-Israeli returns to Jerusalem to join IDF reserves and protect his daughter

children.content: Here in Jerusalem, you see Israeli Defense Force (IDF) soldiers everywhere. Israelis serve in the military once they turn 18, with men serving 32 months and women doing 24 months. After that, almost everyone remains in the reserves until they turn 40.
Israel summoned roughly 360,000 reservists to join the fight against Hamas after the attack on October 7. Many of them were living overseas and they dropped everything to return home.

props.alt: A man pushes a girl on a swing

children.content: Yaacov Travitz flew to Jerusalem after the October 7 attack.
(ABC News: Lauren Day)
The ABC met up with Australian-Israeli Yaacov Travitz in Jerusalem. He was in Australia when the attack happened, and immediately hopped on a plane.

"I was not expecting to come back to fight. I hate fighting. I'm over it. I spent a lot of my life fighting, both in service as well as afterwards in private security. I thought I was done with it but I felt like I was needed and my talents could be put to good use to protect people. "
Yaacov's daughter lives in Jerusalem with his ex-partner, and being here for her was also a big reason for him to come back.

"My hope is that I can keep her safe for long enough until this is over. And then everything goes back to normal, she goes to school, her mum goes to work. And everything just goes back to normal, with people just trying to live without the hate, without the violence."
Yaacov just wants his daughter, who lives in Jerusalem, to have a normal life.
(ABC News: Lauren Day )

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The city of Sderot is one of the closest places you can get to near the Gaza border and you can usually have a clear view into the northern parts of the enclave. Iâve been here watching the war inside Gaza. It means weâve been able to see the evidence of Israeliâs constant bombardment into the north â building after building that is damaged or completely destroyed. The whole area looks like a big grey pile of ash, because any of the buildings that are left standing are covered in concrete dust. Itâs actually pretty eerie to look at. Almost every few seconds, we hear the battle unfolding on the ground. War planes fly overhead and then we hear a huge explosion â we see a massive plume of smoke rise into the sky. Another airstrike. Suddenly there are several loud bangs close by. Israeli tanks stationed near the Gaza border are firing from the ground into the Strip. I see several bright flashes of light, as artillery is fired. I can hear machine guns as Hamas militants are locked in gun battle with Israeli troops on the ground. It sounds like itâs coming from the north but we canât be sure because the Israeli military isnât really telling us a lot of information of whatâs happening on the ground.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Here's what the ABC's Middle East correspondent can see 1km from Gaza's border

children.content: The city of Sderot is one of the closest places you can get to near the Gaza border and you can usually have a clear view into the northern parts of the enclave.

Iâve been here watching the war inside Gaza. It means weâve been able to see the evidence of Israeliâs constant bombardment into the north â building after building that is damaged or completely destroyed.
The whole area looks like a big grey pile of ash, because any of the buildings that are left standing are covered in concrete dust. Itâs actually pretty eerie to look at.

props.alt: An explosion in a night sky

children.content: SderotÂ in southern Israel is as close as journalists can get to Gaza.
(Reuters: Violeta Santos Moura)
Almost every few seconds, we hear the battle unfolding on the ground.
War planes fly overhead and then we hear a huge explosion â we see a massive plume of smoke rise into the sky. Another airstrike.
Suddenly there are several loud bangs close by. Israeli tanks stationed near the Gaza border are firing from the ground into the Strip. I see several bright flashes of light, as artillery is fired.
I can hear machine guns as Hamas militants are locked in gun battle with Israeli troops on the ground.
It sounds like itâs coming from the north but we canât be sure because the Israeli military isnât really telling us a lot of information of whatâs happening on the ground.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Video shows debris, craters and ruined buildings at the Jabalia refugee camp in northern Gaza on Tuesday after the area was hit by Israeli air strikes. An Israeli army spokesperson confirmed the attack to CNN, saying a senior Hamas commander had been in the area. Palestinian health officials said at least 50 people were killed when Israeli air strikes hit the densely populated refugee camp.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's largest bank, Commonwealth Bank, will hike the interest rate on a range of credit cards by up to 1.25 percentage points, according to RateCity. The bank is also raising the international transaction fee on select credit cards from 1 December 2023. From today, the interest rate on eight of CBA's credit cards will rise to 20.99 per cent. These changes follow CBA's increase to the purchase rate on its Low Rate card on 25 August, where the rate was hiked 0.75 percentage points to 13.99 per cent. This rate has not been changed today. "The last thing customers carrying around credit card debt need is a higher interest rate," RateCity research director Sally Tindall said. "If you're someone who can't clear their credit card bill every single month, you should not be holding a card with a rate that's over 15 per cent â even 10 per cent is too high. "There are 14 cards on the market offering rates under 10 per cent, along with five cards that charge fees instead of interest. "At 3.50 per cent, CBA now has one of the highest international transaction fees in the market, but only on select cards."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: CBA hikes interest rate on a range of credit cards

children.content: Australia's largest bank, Commonwealth Bank, will hike the interest rate on a range of credit cards by up to 1.25 percentage points, according to RateCity.
The bank is also raising the international transaction fee on select credit cards from 1 December 2023.
From today, the interest rate on eight of CBA's credit cards will rise to 20.99 per cent.
These changes follow CBA's increase to the purchase rate on its Low Rate card on 25 August, where the rate was hiked 0.75 percentage points to 13.99 per cent. This rate has not been changed today.
"The last thing customers carrying around credit card debt need is a higher interest rate," RateCity research director Sally Tindall
Â
said.
"If you're someone who can't clear their credit card bill every single month, you should not be holding a card with a rate that's over 15 per cent â even 10 per cent is too high.
"There are 14 cards on the market offering rates under 10 per cent, along with five cards that charge fees instead of interest.
"At 3.50 per cent, CBA now has one of the highest international transaction fees in the market, but only on select cards."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An interesting report from the Regional Australia Institute and the Commonwealth Bank, based on CBA customer data that covers around 16 million Australians. It turns out that there are still more Aussies moving from the capital cities to the regions than vice versa, with recent years seeing the reversal of a decades long population drain from regional areas. "In the 12 months to September 2023, capital to regional migration accounted for an 11% share of all relocations, compared to 9.1% making the move from the regions to the city," the report found. While newly arrived migrants from overseas overwhelmingly tend to settle in the big capitals, particularly Sydney and Melbourne, existing residents are still exiting the big smoke, especially Sydney. A stunning 80% of net capital city outflows came from Sydney, with a further 27% from Melbourne â the reason those two cities exceed 100% is that Brisbane (11%) and Perth (5%) are still attracting a lot of internal migrants. In terms of where these people are moving, it is often still reasonably close to home, with regional NSW now the most popular destination (39% of people who left a capital city moved there), followed by Queensland (33%) and Victoria (27%). As for exactly where people are moving, Queensland's Sunshine Coast continued to top the list, followed by Greater Geelong and the Gold Coast in a tie for second, then the Fraser Coast in Queensland and Moorabool in regional Victoria. Lake Macquarie in NSW is also among the most popular destinations for previous city dwellers. As for the biggest growth areas for city slickers to move to over the past year, Mackay in northern Queensland topped the list, along with Douglas and the Whitsundays from the same part of the world, with the Snowy Valleys in NSW and Ceduna in South Australia also making the list. "The increasing popularity of these more remote regional growth hotspots, boosted by good regional job prospects and the likelihood of better house prices and availability, has seen some previously popular LGAs come off the boil," the report noted. "For example, LGAs that had amongst the highest net internal migration inflows a year ago (to September 2022) but reported net outflows over the past 12 months include big regional New South Wales centres such as Wagga Wagga, Dubbo, Bathurst, Albury, Lismore, Newcastle, Byron and Orange as well as Mount Gambier in South Australia and West Tamar in Tasmania."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australians continue to move from the cities to regions above pre-COVID levels

children.content: An interesting report from the
Regional Australia Institute and the Commonwealth Bank
, based on CBA customer data that covers around 16 million Australians.

It turns out that there are still more Aussies moving from the capital cities to the regions than vice versa, with recent years seeing the reversal of a decades long population drain from regional areas.
"In the 12 months to September 2023, capital to regional migration accounted for an 11% share of all relocations, compared to 9.1% making the move from the regions to the city," the report found.

props.alt: Inflows from capitals to the regions continue to exceed outflows

children.content: Inflows from capitals to the regions continue to exceed outflows.
(CBA/RAI)
While newly arrived migrants from overseas overwhelmingly tend to settle in the big capitals, particularly Sydney and Melbourne, existing residents are still exiting the big smoke, especially Sydney.
A stunning
80% of net capital city outflows came from Sydney, with a further 27% from Melbourne
â the reason those two cities exceed 100% is that Brisbane (11%) and Perth (5%) are still attracting a lot of internal migrants.
In terms of where these people are moving, it is often still reasonably close to home, with
regional NSW now the most popular destination (39% of people who left a capital city moved there), followed by Queensland (33%) and Victoria (27%)
As for exactly where people are moving,
Queensland's Sunshine Coast continued to top the list, followed by Greater Geelong and the Gold Coast in a tie for second, then the Fraser Coast in Queensland and Moorabool in regional Victoria
Lake Macquarie in NSW
is also among the most popular destinations for previous city dwellers.
As for the biggest growth areas for city slickers to move to over the past year,
Mackay in northern Queensland topped the list, along with Douglas and the Whitsundays from the same part of the world, with the Snowy Valleys in NSW and Ceduna in South Australia
also making the list.

"The increasing popularity of these more remote regional growth hotspots, boosted by good regional job prospects and the likelihood of better house prices and availability, has seen some previously popular LGAs come off the boil," the report noted.

"For example, LGAs that had amongst the highest net internal migration inflows a year ago (to September 2022) but reported net outflows over the past 12 months include big regional New South Wales centres such as Wagga Wagga, Dubbo, Bathurst, Albury, Lismore, Newcastle, Byron and Orange as well as Mount Gambier in South Australia and West Tamar in Tasmania."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New research from Roy Morgan shows a record high 1.57 million mortgage holders, representing 30.3 per cent of mortgage holders were "at risk" of mortgage stress in the three months to September. The figures, which cover the period of the three RBA meetings at which interest rates were left unchanged, represent a new record high â up 7,000 on a month ago. The number of Australians "at risk" of mortgage stress has increased by 766,000 since May 2022 when the RBA began a cycle of interest rate increases. The record high of 35.6 per cent of mortgage holders in mortgage stress was reached in mid-2008, during the global financial crisis. Other data released today by Core Logic, shows national home prices rose 0.9 per cent in October, with the biggest increases were in Perth (+1.6 per cent), Brisbane (+1.4 per cent) and Adelaide (+1.4 per cent). Ray Morgan says the number of mortgage holders considered "extremely at risk" â if even the "interest only" component of a loan is over a certain proportion of household income â is now numbered at 1.43 million (20.5 per cent) which is significantly above the long-term average over the last 15 years of 15.3 per cent. The RBA cash rate is currently at 4.10 per cent â the highest official interest rates since May 2012. Roy Morgan has modelled the impact of two potential RBA interest rate increases of 0.25 per cent in both November and December, which would take the cash rate to 4.6 per cent. It says the numbers of mortgage holders in stress would increase to 1.58 million, or 30.4 per cent â an increase of 8,000 â if the RBA increases interest rates next week. Then, if the RBA raises interest rates by a further 0.25 per cent in December to 4.6 per cent, there will be 31 per cent of mortgage holders, or 1.61 million considered "at risk" â an increase of 39,000. Ray Morgan CEO Michele Levine says the RBA left interest rates unchanged at its last four meetings, but with last month's inflation read higher, "these pressures are adding to calls for the RBA to raise interest rates again and are a key factor for why we have modelled two further interest rate increases". Mortgage stress is measured by when mortgage repayments are greater than a certain percentage of household income. Interest rates are only one of the variables that determines whether a mortgage holder is considered "at risk". The variable that has the largest impact on whether a borrower falls into the "at risk" category is related to household income â which is directly related to employment. "If there is a sharp rise in unemployment, mortgage stress is set to increase even more," Ms Levine said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: More than 1.57 million Australians are now 'at risk' of 'mortgage stress'

Other data released today by Core Logic

Ray Morgan says the number of mortgage holders considered "extremely at risk" â if even the "interest only" component of a loan is over a certain proportion of household income â is now numbered at 1.43 million (20.5 per cent) which is significantly above the long-term average over the last 15 years of 15.3 per cent.
The RBA cash rate is currently at 4.10 per cent â the highest official interest rates since May 2012.

It says the numbers of mortgage holders in stress would increase to 1.58 million, or 30.4 per cent â an increase of 8,000 â if the RBA increases interest rates next week.

Then, if the RBA raises interest rates by a further 0.25 per cent in December to 4.6 per cent, there will be 31 per cent of mortgage holders, or 1.61 million considered "at risk" â an increase of 39,000.
Ray Morgan
CEO Michele Levine

says the RBA left interest rates unchanged at its last four meetings, but with last month's inflation read higher, "these pressures are adding to calls for the RBA to raise interest rates again and are a key factor for why we have modelled two further interest rate increases".
Mortgage stress is measured by when mortgage repayments are greater than a certain percentage of household income.
Interest rates are only one of the variables that determines whether a mortgage holder is considered "at risk".
The variable that has the largest impact on whether a borrower falls into the "at risk" category is related to household income â which is directly related to employment.
